"Oh, delightful," I muttered, setting down my paintbrush as I noticed the breakfast plate, untouched save for the cooled coffee turning it into a Jackson Pollock of its own accord. He'd slipped out again, like a shadow at dawn, without so much as a rustle of the sheets to wake me.

The clock ticked, each second a mocking gavel in my mind's courtroom. "Guilty," it pronounced, "of being asleep when you should've been awake, present, supportive." I could almost see the headlines: 'Artist Abandons Partner in Time of Need,' 'Sleeping Beauty Fails at Relationship.'

I sighed, leaning back in my chair, imagining the worst. He'd probably had another nightmare, one of those soul-crushing ones that left him drenched in cold sweat and silent tears. And I, like a useless sponge, had been fast asleep, snoring away while he suffered alone.

'What if it happens again?' I thought, a shiver running down my spine. 'What if next time he can't handle it? What if... what if he leaves for good?'

But no, that was ridiculous. Dramatic, even. We'd weathered storms before, hadn't we? Yet, the thought lingered, a dark cloud on an otherwise sunny day. I picked up my brush again, determined to finish this painting, to prove to myself that I could still be productive despite the looming doom in my mind's eye.

After all," I said aloud, as if convincing an invisible jury, "tomorrow is another day." But even as I spoke, the words tasted bitter on my tongue, like a lie waiting to be exposed.
